Posts.Content: Hi ctrigg, We have some information here on Vitamin D on this page about Revitalising yourself after Breast Cancer, which says "Did you know that any cancer treatment in women that lowers oestrogen levels can increase the risk of osteoporosis. Calcium can help to strengthen your bones and reduce this risk, but for your body to use calcium, you also need vitamin D." Jess

Posts.Content: Hi Rubix19, I'm so sorry to hear that this has happened to you. You might find it helpful to ask a question in our Ask a nurse section. I really hope you get some support on here and find it a helpful place to be. All the best, Jess Macmillan Community Team

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne, I'm really sorry to read your story and about the difficulties you are having with your husband. It must be hard to ask such a personal question and I hope you get some replies soon from other members who may have had a similar situation. We have lots of information about Sex, relationships and cancer on our site, and many videos talking about this too. We also have some information here about Cancer and sexuality and coping with sexual difficulties. This section talks if you don't feel like sex and other problems you may experience after having cancer. We also have written a blog on Cancer and your sex life.  Please feel free to call our support line about this issue as well, as our nurses are ready to answer any questions which you may have about cancer and the issues surrounding it. The number is 0808 808 0000, and lines are open 9-8, Mon-Fri. Wishing you all the best, Jess Macmillan Community Team

It explains a lot about the different types of vaccines (live vaccines, inactivated vaccines, re-vaccination) and how chemo can affect it. You might also find it helpful to call our support line for free and speak to a cancer information nurse on 0808 808 0000 (Mon-Fri, 9-8.) I hope some of this is useful, Jess Macmillan Community Team
Posts.Title: Life after chemo - immunisations/vaccinations

Posts.Content: Hi Suzy24,  This all sounds so horrible for your mum and your family, I'm so sorry that it seems that the cancer keeps coming back, especially at this time of year. I really hope you find some help and support here on the community, and there are other places you can go too. You may know that we have a free support line on 0808 808 0000, open Mon-Fri, 9am-8pm. There you can get advice and support about your mum's cancer and treatment, as well as support for yourself as someone affected by cancer. The staff are really lovely and are happy to help.  We also have a Family and friends group, where you may find someone in a similar situation.  I really hope this helps and best wishes, Jess Macmillan Community Team

Posts.Title: Diep Flap or not

Posts.Content: I saw these lovely ladies on the news a while ago who have started making knitted knockers- handmade cotton prosthesis for women who have had mastectomies or other breast surgery. They were started by women in the US who wanted to have a more comfortable alternative to a regular prosthesis. It is an entirely charity run organisation and relies on the public knitting these individual prostheses. Their site is: www.knittedknockersuk.com Here you can see their facebook knitting group too- Knitted Knockers UK Knitting group Jess Macmillan Community Team

Posts.Title: Difference between Grade 1 and Stage 1

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, We passed this discussion onto our Brave the shave fundraising team and here is their response - Thank you for sharing your thoughts on this forum. We appreciate all feedback as it helps us to grow and to support more people affected by cancer.  Please accept our apologies if the campaign has caused any upset or offence, Brave the Shave was created in order to raise awareness and vital funds for Macmillan and we understand the sensitive nature of the campaign. Brave the Shave started as we found that many Macmillan supporters were choosing to shave their head and fundraise for Macmillan. Originally we launched Shave or Style, however from this campaign, we found that the majority of participants were opting to shave and so moved forward with that aspect specifically. We wanted to provide these supporters with a better platform in order to raise money, while sharing their fundraising activity. The majority of people who take part in Brave the Shave have a close connection to cancer, including the ladies in our TV ad. We do understand that this type of event is not for everyone, which is why we offer a variety of events, including Coffee Morning, Go Sober and Summer Lights. We also of course are continually trying to improve and check our communication with this particular ask, which is why yours and participants feedback here is so important.   Last year this event raised over £4m to support people affected by cancer, which means we can continue to be there for more people affected by cancer than ever before. We hope this response has eased some of your concerns, and please do let us know if you have any further comments or queries, you can email us at bravetheshave@macmillan.org.uk
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, Here is another response from the fundraising team who have been following this discussion and all your comments - "We are very sorry to hear you find the event name and some of the language used in the Brave the Shave campaign upsetting, it is very helpful to hear your feedback. We do consult with people affected by cancer in developing our campaigns and your comments have definitely reinforced our commitment to carry out a thorough piece of research on Brave the Shave with our Cancer Voice groups to ensure the messaging and tone of voice is appropriate and reflecting real people’s experiences and feelings. Thank you so much for your feedback again." Thanks, Jess Macmillan Community Team
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi all, Our Brave the Shave team have written a response after reading through your comments on this discussion: 'Thank you for sharing your thoughts on Brave the Shave, we have been reading and following all your comments and are very sorry to hear that this campaign has caused upset and anger to many of you, this is absolutely not our intention. We know that deciding to shave your head for charity and losing your hair during cancer treatment are worlds apart and we are in no way trying to compare the two experiences. The majority of people taking part tell us they are doing so because a loved one has or is going through cancer and they want to do something significant to raise money for Macmillan. The purpose of our fundraising campaigns is to raise money so we can continue to provide vital services to people with cancer during treatment and beyond and this is why Brave the Shave exists. To date the event has raised over £17 million to support people living with cancer and their families.  Some of you have asked questions about where the hair from Brave the Shave goes. We actively encourage people taking part in the event to donate their hair to the Little Princess Trust by sending all participants a detailed leaflet and emails on how to go about doing this. The Little Princess Trust help us track this activity so we know that last year hair donations from Brave the Shave fundraisers helped make 43 more wigs for boys and girls across the UK and Ireland who have lost their own hair through cancer treatment and other illness. We are committed to listening to feedback and gathering thoughts from people affected by cancer about Brave the Shave. Since the event launched in 2015 we have continually used feedback to shape the event. This year we have spoken to people living with, and affected by, cancer to get a broad range of feedback and have made adjustments to the event’s look and feel. Our findings have given us the confidence that Brave the Shave is an appropriate fundraising campaign for Macmillan. We realise Brave the Shave is not for everyone but I do hope this has given you some useful insights into our campaign. I will make sure that your thoughts around the campaign are taken on board as we continue to review this year’s campaign.' If you have any more feedback I'd suggest using our feedback form to contact the team, as the community is primarily used for peer support and none of our fundraising team spend time on here, so it may be easily missed. Best wishes, Jess
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi jannie13, I'm afraid I'm not from the fundraising team so I can't comment on your question. I will pass on your comments though. Many thanks, Jess

If you have anything you would like to pass on directly, you may like to do this via our feedback form. Many thanks, Jess Macmillan Community Team

Posts.Title: let down again

Posts.Content: Hi both, Dreamthief - There is a 'remember me' button on the mobile site as well yes, after user feedback said this is something they'd like. Monika123 -  I understand that many people use Facebook and find it easy to use. Of course, we are always trying to find new ways to make our site easier and simpler to use for our members. One benefit to the current Online Community which Dreamthief has already mentioned, is that many users find it helpful to read the advice of others, and don't always find it necessary to post something for themselves. As a charity, we want to be open and share our knowledge and experiences with others, as this can be invaluable in itself. We take our members' privacy very seriously and this is why we don't allow full names to be used, and moderate when users post their private details such as their email addresses and phone numbers. Facebook is public, which would mean that some users would have to create separate private or 'fake' accounts to their personal ones to avoid their personal details being exposed in these groups. There are also technical limitations to using Facebook- one being that we have over 100 groups here on the community, which would mean 100 Facebook groups.  I hope this clears up some of the reasons we do this, and if you ever need to get in touch with us, the quickest way to get a response is to drop us an email at community@macmillan.org.uk and we'll be happy to answer your questions, or suggestions. All the best, Jess Macmillan community team

Posts.Title: Silly radiotherapy question -

Posts.Content: Hi Denise, Happy Christmas to you too! I'm sorry you are experiencing such discomfort after surgery and radiotherapy. I'm afraid I cannot personally help you but you might benefit from calling our Macmillan support line? It is free to call and you can speak to a cancer information specialist who knows a lot about side effects and cancer treatment. The number is 0808 808 0000 and they are normally open 9-8 Mon-Fri, however it is slightly different over the Christmas period. 22 December: open, 9am-8pm 23 December: open, 9am-5pm 24-28 December: closed 29-30 December: open, 9am-8pm 31 December: open, 9am-5pm 1 January: closed Best wishes and I hope it doesn't spoil your Christmas, Jess Macmillan Community Team

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, Breast Cancer Care have loads of great support available which you might all like to take a look at. They hold lingerie evenings for people who might be struggling to find a bra or swimming costume to fit after breast cancer. I've contacted them but haven't heard back about any that are happening any time soon but this might be a good thing to ask about? Has anyone else ever attended one of these events? Jess
